properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather is expected. Timing: Friday through Saturday evening. The heat event may persist into Sunday. Maximum temperatures Friday: 31 to 33 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 40). Maximum temperatures Saturday: 32 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 40). Minimum overnight temperatures: 18 to 20 degrees Celsius. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-20T00:42:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-19T08:43:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2506703137.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather is expected. Timing: Today through Saturday evening. The heat event may persist into Sunday. Maximum temperatures Friday: 31 to 33 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 40). Maximum temperatures Saturday: 32 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 40). Minimum overnight temperatures: 18 to 20 degrees Celsius. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The record-breaking hot weather is expected to continue. Time span: continuing today, with a break for the east on Saturday. Parts of the province will be close to warning criteria next week. Maximum temperatures today: 32 to 37 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 42). Maximum temperatures Saturday: near 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34). Locations: New Brunswick. Remarks: Eastern regions will see a reprieve on Saturday but more heat is possible beginning early next week for most of the province. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-19T23:38:56-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall possible tonight. A few rounds of thunderstorms have soaked the region again tonight. Additional rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm are expected in many areas by Friday morning. Environment Canada continues to closely monitor this situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 29 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 14 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 2 days. Above normal temperatures are expected for Wrigley for the next couple of days. Temperatures are expected to moderate on Sunday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot temperatures is expected to continue. Time span: continuing today, tonight and for most of the mainland once again on Saturday. Maximum Temperature today: 32 to 36 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 39). Maximum Temperature Saturday: 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 35). Minimum Temperatures: 17 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: inland areas of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Temperatures will return to more seasonal values over northern Nova Scotia and Cape Breton on Saturday. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-19T23:37:56-00:00

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Minimum temperatures: near plus 1. Location: the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: early Saturday morning. Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form as partly clear skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has developed at Sachs Harbour and Ulukhaktok. The fog is expected to dissipate later tonight at Sachs Harbour and Friday morning at Ulukhaktok. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-19T18:29:54-00:00
